column4: Hi there - has anyone a valid list of all possible Xkboptions and their meaning ? the manpage doesn't describe waht is possible
XKB is a very mysterious horror. But try looking at 'man setxkbmap' for some hints.
not necesasarily! Do you use KDE?
yes I use KDE but after a while playing wiht diverse xkb files I don't have these multiple opitons in accessability/keyboardlayout anymore ....
bad news... But you don't need special XKB files for that, it is a set of standard options.
for example statically I use:     Option  "XkbSymbols" "en_US(pc105)+gb+group(toggle)+compose(ralt)"
or dynamically, generated by the control panel: setxkbmap -option -option compose:rwin,lv3:lwin_switch,grp:toggle,altwin:meta_alt
try the latter for example it might give you some fleeting moment of happiness. If you are lucky.
I give it a try, thanks!
it is obsolete, and can interfere with proper XKB.
so whre do you specify what characters appear when pressing certain keys, if xmodmap is obsolete?
tragically in an XKB config file, which is far more complex.
Compose is not the same as Group Switch which is not the same as ISO Level 3
even if Group Switch and ISO Level 3 are pretty similar, and usually configured the same.
I am totally confused...... I have an us layout Sun Type 6 Keyboard and all I want is the effect that when I press Compose + a I get an german umlaut
I already managed to get this in debian Sarge
you cant do that....
Compose requires _two_ keys to follow that.
to get "a" with umlaut with Compose you press Compose+:+a
or else you press GroupSwitc+a
